newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistani mill owners plead for raw sugar import.
newsitem.headline: Pakistani mill owners plead for raw sugar import.

text.p: Pakistani sugar mill owners pleaded on Thursday for the import of raw sugar instead of refined white crystal sugar, saying this could save at least $50 million a year in foreign exchange.

"We should concentrate on importing raw sugar instead of refined sugar," Khadim Ali Qazilbash, secretary general of the Pakistan Sugar Mills Association, told Reuters, adding that raw sugar costs about $60 a tonne less than refined sugar.
"Some sugar mills imported raw sugar and sold it after refining in the past few weeks," he said. "The experiment was very encouraging."

Mian Fawad Ahmed Sheikh, a director of Fatima Sugar Mills near the central city of Multan, said he had imported 5,000 tonnes of raw sugar, refined it and sold it for a moderate profit. He has now imported another 12,000 tonnes of raw sugar.
Sheikh said buying raw sugar from abroad could keep mills, which now operate seasonally, busy for the whole year.
"The only drawback is the government's high excise duty," he said. "If it is waived, then refined sugar could be cheaper than that produced by crushing locally cultivated sugarcane."
He was speaking one day before Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz was due to present his budget for fiscal 1997/98 (July-June).
"Pakistan could earn foreign exchange by refining raw sugar and exporting refined sugar as is done in China, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates and other countries," Sheikh said.
Pakistan imported 518,976 tonnes of sugar worth $197 million in the first 10 months of 1996/97, compared to a negligible 2,759 tonnes in the year-ago period.
In April sugar imports rose to 34,388 tonnes worth $12 million compared to 16,134 tonnes worth $6 million in March.
Mill owners had hoped to produce 2.65 million tonnes in 1996/97, but output had reached only 2.32 million by April 15 due to a shortage of sugarcane.
Qazilbash said production was likely to reach 2.38 million tonnes by the end of the year, compared to 2.47 million tonnes in 1995/96 and three million tonnes in 1994/95.

Sugar consumption is likely to rise to 2.85 million tonnes in 1997/98, up from an expected 2.7 million tonnes this year, he said. The forecast includes 1.8 million tonnes for domestic use, 900,000 tonnes for industry and 150,000 tonnes for Afghanistan.
